text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
i'm gonna share with you a dish that's called

moo manao which literally means lime pork but 
what it actually is is this tender slices of

pork drench in this garlicky spicy lime dressing 
and then you have that with some vegetables it's

a healthy easy super refreshing dish that I don't 
know why I haven't made it up until now but it's

been requested recently and I kind of remembered 
oh yeah that's a great one so there you go after

years what I kitchen Mumma now let's get started 
so the choice of pork is very important because

as you see this dish is like the pork is the 
absolute star I am using pork but thinly sliced

and I choose pork but because it's more flavorful 
there's fat on it you could get away with pork

loin as well if you want something leaner but you 
want thin thin thin slices and I'm gonna season

this with some soy sauce not too much because 
the dressing will have a lot of flavor so you

don't want the pork to be too salty it's just 
some seasoning and as you can see the pork can

be sticky to help them slide easily from each 
other I'm gonna add just a tiny little bit of

oil poured from this tiny little thing that I 
got from my trip to Japan just look how cute I

just could not not get this right it's exactly 1 
tablespoon now I'm also gonna add some water and

once the pork has time to marinate it's going to 
absorb all of that water make it more plump more

juicy now some cornstarch cornstarch in marinade 
ends up being what's called velvety and velvety is

basically when you create a layer of film around 
meat and when you cook it that layer of film kind

of seals in all the juices the Chinese do it a lot 
Thai people do it a lot too and that cornstarch is

gonna be our film right there but for this I'm 
doing a very light velvety you don't want to

overdo it because otherwise it can get slimy if 
you put too much velvet hang on looks like more

liquid now but trust me once it has a chance to 
sit it will absorb some of that so give this at

least 20 minutes more than that if you can but 20 
is an absolute minimum the dressing is super super

simple and all the basics to Thai cuisine so of 
course a chili and for this I like to go with a

bigger one so I get more color out of it and or 
you can put more and some garlic I'm gonna pound

that down into a paste all right so once it's 
sort of ground up into a paste I'm just gonna

add my palm sugar like chopped palm sugar and 
that is gonna give us some more abrasion help

break down some of the more stubborn pieces 
and of course some fish sauce and if you've

got good fancy fish sauce now's the time to use 
it because it's a dish that's light fish sauce

flavor is prominent this is when you're gonna 
taste the difference and this is Mumma now you

got to add some now which is lime juice lots 
and lots of lime juice to finish it off with

some greenery I've got some chopped cilantro 
throwing it in there if you don't like cilantro

you can do green onions instead and that is it it 
is done alright so time to cook the pork so mumma

now is typically just blanched in boiling water 
which I've got right in front of me here and in

Thailand we actually blanch protein a lot it's 
quick and easy now as you can see the pork has

absorbed much of the liquid like there's barely 
any pooling liquid left that's what we want that

means the pork is super juicy now when it comes 
to blanching protein you can overcook the pork

very easily therefore what I'm going to do is I'm 
going to cook blanch the pork in this sieve here

and this means that when it's done I can lift 
the whole thing out I don't have to spend time

like fishing around for it and so that's way I 
can ensure I don't overcook it all of this is

going in at once and it's literally going to take 
15 seconds the pork is so thin I'm just gonna use

chopsticks to spread them out and you want to 
use a wide sift for this so all the little bits

of velvetine can fall through and you don't end up 
dragging it all out that's it now I'm also going

to dunk it in my bowl of warm water right here 
and that's just ensure that sometimes you know

there's bits of the cornstarch mixture that's in 
there and I'm just kind of rinsing it to get rid

of any extra cornstarch bits because a dressing 
so light if you've got like any extra cornstarch

but sometimes you do feel a bit of a like a 
slipperiness in your mouth so we don't want any

of that and that is done for the pork so we are 
ready to serve but we need some fresh vegetables

to sort of help balance the heaviness of the 
meatiness of the pork so typically it's served

with some shredded cabbage to line the bottom 
of the plate and also some fresh vegetables and

classically they used raw Chinese broccoli the 
stems and the leaves but I prefer broccoli stems

because I find Chinese broccoli raw sometimes 
it's a little bitter so I just take broccoli

stems and I peel the outside because the outside 
can be tough soak it in some cold water and it's

crisp and cold goes really well with the pork 
I got some mint leaves to go you know for some

people who want to munch on mint as well it's 
really really nice so here you got your pork on

the bed of cabbage ooh I can feel with my tongue 
how soft the pork is ooh I'm salivating already

and you could toss the park with the dressing 
but it just looks better when all the bits of

garlic and chilies sort of resting on top of the 
pork so good look at that and you got to make

sure make sure there's no bald spots anywhere 
and now I'm gonna put just some mint leaves on

top because it's so cute and there you have it 
Mumma now so easy so delicious as I am about to

show you can you make sure I get some part oh 
that's a big one some cabbage so the cabbage is

not just there to like garnish the plate or to 
make it look like there's more pork than there

actually is it really does go well together I want 
to make sure I get a mint mmm oh that's so good

the texture of that pork is unreal it's soft 
its tender but it's got a bit of a bounce and

that's why I prefer pork butt to because it 
does have that bounce that pork loin doesn't

have it's garlicky its blimey it's spicy the 
perfect balance of sour and salty and spicy

and the vegetables really do balance it out you 
can have this with rice you can have this just

on its own and somebody on my Instagram said 
that looks like it would be good in a taco

answer you are absolutely right it would be so 
good in a taco so the recipe as always will be

on hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make it send 
me a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram oh

and also I am on Pinterest as well if any of you 
are pinners and if you haven't subscribed to the

show make sure you do so you don't miss an episode 
and make sure you click the little bell icon to

get a notification when I post a new video if you 
love the show and you want to support us check out

our patreon link in the description below and I 
will see you next time for your next deviation hi
